summary: This document is a chain of emails from August 10-13, 2019, between attorneys and federal prosecutors following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It centers on attorney Martin Weinberg's requests for the preservation of all evidence related to Epstein's detention and death, and discussions about legal privilege review of seized electronic devices. It reveals immediate post-death legal maneuvering and evidence preservation concerns.

persons.name: Martin Weinberg
persons.context: Primary author of the evidence preservation request sent to prosecutors on behalf of Epstein's family following his death. He asserts attorney-client privilege over communications on seized devices and coordinates with the estate.

persons.name: Michael Miller
persons.context: A primary recipient of the correspondence from Martin Weinberg. He is involved in coordinating the government's response regarding evidence preservation and the privilege review process for seized devices.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Copied on the email chain, involved in the legal discussions concerning Jeffrey Epstein's case following his death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case (US v Epstein). The emails discuss the preservation of evidence related to his detention, attempted suicide, and death.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as having personal counsel who will also receive the evidence preservation request from Martin Weinberg.

connections.description: Weinberg states he had prior privileged communications with Epstein and is now acting on behalf of Epstein's family regarding evidence preservation.
Engaged in direct correspondence regarding legal procedures, evidence preservation, and scheduling calls in the aftermath of Epstein's death.
Both are attorneys copied on the same email chain discussing case-related matters post-Epstein's death.
Both are correspondents on the email chain, with Miller representing the prosecution and Weingarten being part of the defense/estate legal discussions.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Epstein's Attempted Suicide
events.description: An occurrence investigated as an attempted suicide by Jeffrey Epstein while in detention at the MCC.

events.title: Legal Discussions on Evidence and Privilege
events.description: Email correspondence between attorneys and prosecutors regarding the preservation of evidence from Epstein's death and the process for reviewing privileged material on seized electronic devices.

events.title: Initiation of FBI Investigation
events.description: An FBI investigation into Epstein's death was initiated, as confirmed in the email chain.

locations: 9th floor (MCC unit where Epstein was held)
keyFacts: Attorney Martin Weinberg, on behalf of Epstein's family, sent a comprehensive request for the preservation of all evidence related to Epstein's detention and death on August 10, 2019, just days after the event.

The request specifically seeks videos from the MCC's 9th floor from the evening of August 9 through the morning of August 10, staff logs, inmate lists, medical records, and any note found in Epstein's cell.

Weinberg raised concerns about attorney-client privilege, asking for assurance that a 'taint team' would review seized electronic devices (from the Virgin Islands, NY, or NJ) before prosecutors, to protect communications with Epstein's various lawyers.
The email chain confirms that an FBI investigation into Epstein's death was initiated immediately on August 10, 2019.

The correspondence reveals immediate and detailed legal coordination between Epstein's estate attorneys and federal prosecutors in the hours and days following his death, focusing on evidence control and procedural safeguards.
